summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons medical emergency report and clinical encounter documenting the response to Jeffrey Epstein being found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. It details the resuscitation efforts, including CPR, AED use, intubation, and medication administration, before he was transported to a local emergency room.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, subject of the medical emergency and resuscitation efforts.

persons.name: MaIN Biteau
persons.context: Individual who generated the consultation request document.

persons.name: Provider Bala RN
persons.context: Listed as the team leader/provider during the resuscitation event.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive on the floor of his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. Correctional officers initiated CPR. He was cold, had circumferential bruising around the neck and posterior mottling, with fixed and dilated pupils and no palpable pulses.

events.title: Resuscitation Efforts at MCC
events.description: Medical staff and paramedics performed extensive resuscitation on Epstein, including continued CPR, AED placement (no shock advised), placement of an IV, oxygen via BVM, intubation, and administration of epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate. Cardiac monitor showed asystole.

events.title: Transport to Local Emergency Room
events.description: Epstein was transported to a local emergency room with CPR still in progress after approximately 35-40 minutes of on-site resuscitation efforts failed to restore a pulse.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at approximately 6:33 a.m. on August 10, 2019.
The report notes 'circumferential Bruising around the neck' upon finding him.
Resuscitation efforts began immediately with CPR by correctional officers and continued by medical staff, but the inmate remained in asystole (no cardiac electrical activity).
Epstein was intubated and received multiple rounds of epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate before being transported to a local ER.
The document is a primary source medical record detailing the immediate response to Epstein's medical emergency leading to his death.
